positive.review: Good game. Had to uninstall, as this became too addictive

While the game could technically go on forever, in terms of unlocking new content, it's very short. I think that's a good thing though because a worse dev would have just made you sit around forever in-between unlocks.
If you enjoy these types of games then this one is worth your time.

This game is a 7/10
Not the best idle game on the market. Many sections are linear with only one path to follow, and the game doesn't reward you much for trying to do things "your way". Additionally, I personally don't like the ratio mechanic to split resources.

YET, the game is still enjoyable and most importantly[h3][b] the game is free [/b][/h3].

Entertaining, good graphical design, interesting mechanics. Satisfying to organize the little window boxes for each node such that the lines look nice.

Some notes:
Ratio slider either needs finer control over percentages of the two outputs, or to give the player more agency over choosing the actual ratios. Its job is to be a resource splitter, and it fails at it spectacularly, compared to the built-in splitting of input-to-output connections. 
Forcing it to be some multiple of 10% limits its usefulness, when a better implementation would allow for more than 2 outputs with something like an 8:4:1 ratio (which is easier to make with the mergers due to their expanding inputs)

Upgrades need to have an option to dismiss or hide. After I get the permanent 'Antivirus Pro' perk, I don't want to clutter my menu with its inferior version, so I wont buy the upgrade after prestiging. Same thing with obsolete file value upgrades (which I might care about if they improved research output).
A hide / collapse option would be handy for other menu items, such as the default collector or the part of the node interface of the network limiter / exchanger for whichever internet type I'm not using.

Small nitpick: the data refiner and pre-analyzer node placers should go in the research tab... otherwise it feels too empty. At least in early-mid game.

Also, having a different node for each type of file type and coin miner feels clunky and redundant. I could see an implementation of a tool tip based menu / drop down selection thing, with an explanation of how to use it in the tutorial, working quite well...
The ability to upgrade my nodes from their construction icons would give them a reason to remain in the menu after placing them. I know certain upgradable nodes can get a second, but like, little orange arrow notification that is bottom center aligned when solo and on each lower corner when duo'd. Same thing would go for the CPU & GPU cores and clock speed.

The requests tab under achievements needs an indicator that it has unclaimed rewards, ie if you are currently viewing achievements and looking for where the claimables are.

Keyboard shortcuts? (Other than copying / pasting)
o.o

Lastly, maybe make the request uploader have a secondary output when throwing things in it that don't fulfill requests? Given that you cant get stuff back out of it... Otherwise it feels a bit useless.

Otherwise, I like this game, and would recommend it if you have enjoyed similar games such as shapez.io or Factorio. Bring your own music and get in the zone for a few hours.

Upload Labs is a clean, lightweight automation idle game where you connect downloaders, processors, and uploaders to build efficient data networks. It is easy to learn, satisfying to optimize, and great for short play sessions.

This is a promising semi-idle NGU, but in its current state it feels a bit too straightforward. The progression is clear, but it lacks the complexity, typical for the genre. The automation features are quite basic and I was surprised to find almost any background narrative - meaning low tier memes, was missing, which often helps build a friendlier rapport with the devs. Still solid product, feels smooth, animations and soundtrack are nice. Passionately waiting for more robust features and content in upcoming updates that will constantly ruin my 100% badge on this game for like 2 more years, classic.
Minimalistic design with addictive gameplay and achievable progression without pay to win or Ads.
An game to learn and develop and relax which make intrested a teche peoples
Fun game with interesting mechanics and complex creations

what a little gem of a game. the graphics are as simple as can be but the core gameplay is really solid. i'd even confidently say it might be already up there along with factorio or satisfactory. it certainly is as addicting as those two. booted it up just to check it out after appearing on my recommended but had to uninstall after playing for 5 hours straight. looking forward to playing more in the future seeing as the devs are currently working hard on more updates.

[b] can't believe it's free as well. if the devs ever decided to price this $5-7 i wouldn't even be mad, just wonder what took them so long [/b]
Peak, love this game. I wish they add more content sooner (no pressure). picking this for sit back and relax XD
dopamine whenever i unlock something but it also takes absolutely forever to unlock anything even for an idle game

I really enjoyed this one, but I don't think everyone will. I like Idler's that reward you for [i] not [/i] idling. This game allows you to near constantly micromanage, improve, expand, and optimize your build. You probably already know if that's your vibe or not, but you know...It's free, no harm in giving it a try.

Really nice production chain optimisation idler. The graphics are super-clean, easy to understand.

I appreciate there being a few systems that obviously do interact with each other, but each one of them is a world of its own and each one of them works completely differently, that brings enjoyable variety to the game.

It is free to play, completely fine to play with option to support the dev that speeds your journey up a bit, definitely not required, very sensible, kudos

amazing game! 
uhhhhhhh...
its just entertaining i guess.
cant think of anything else tho.

A lot of people have been reviewing saying its a "boring idle game" and I get why, but I don't think that's a truly fair analysis on the whole game.

 I thoroughly enjoy this game, something about building networks, yes it's a samey similar gameplay loop of upgrade, level up, upgrade etc, but there is so much network optimisation and bottleneck finding and research tree stuff to complete which keeps the game feeling fresh and different, and if that tickles your brain, then this game is very enjoyable. Some people leaving negative reviews just might not enjoy this style of gameplay.

Also seen reviews of people saying the game forces you in to buying the upgrade DLC, and that's simply not the case. Have some patience, log off, touch grass, use the rest bonus, and you will never need to spend a penny.

Oh, and not to mention, IT'S A FREE GAME.

very fun game about optimization and what not but i need an end game man... like a final goal

The only critique I'll give is that I wish that the Application/Coding nodes had a better description so that I wasn't lost in the menu looking back and forth at the different descriptions. Would possibly also be better if there was tutorial for setting up the Application/Coding nodes instead of the "fumble-through-it-yourself" set up that it currently is.

Fairly well laid out game - not really a clicker, primarily an automation/factory idler game, where most of what you're managing is logistics and visual layout. There are in-game purchases, but they *are* optional, and it doesn't look like any achievements rely on them.
excellent game even if its was paid at start i wood have bought it. Super fun

Really fun idle game that seems simple at first and quickly becomes about optimizing your resources to progress faster. Heard some negative reviews calling it pay to win and honestly not at all. I have not purchased any of the DLCs and while their perks look interesting from just normal gameplay you can easily do everything and you gain many ways to earn tokens normally as you unlock more game mechanics. Mainly wanted to write a review saying anyone who believes this game is pay to win is not someone who plays idle games or did not make it far enough into the game to realize you can earn tokens from more ways than random spawns. And even the random spawns are frequent enough that you can purchase many upgrades from tokens just from that alone easily

Simple little idle game, can reach end game within 3 days, achievements are easy to get apart from the "back-end dev" achievement which is just gonna take me ~20 hours of afk time.

Nothing really bothered me while playing, apart from pasting blueprints, since the nodes spawn in weirdly and not where you put em when you made the blueprint, so after pasting a blueprint you'd have to spend a minute or so just putting the nodes back to where they look nice, which is just ocd, after a while i gave up on doing it, since you paste blueprints so often, after every reset it wasn't worth doing everytime.

Also idk if this is a game engine issue because "clicker heroes" has the same weird behaviour, but if i have my sim-wheel plugged in, for some reason my brake pedal axis makes the game scroll down, in CH that result in scroll bars going down, in this game it resulted in my camera panning down, so i kept having to unplug my wheel when wanting to play this.

Waiting on the release of version 2 now, which was teased a couple days ago.

The game is fun and gives you some play hours.

[h1] Feedback for the dev [/h1]
3 things that are sadly a bit scuffed / missing
- the quick connect function just stops working sometimes for no reason.
- a quick way to remove connections with a single press when an option is selected.
- give the player the option to set a % for overclocking / splitt functions
Great game, i just love it. Hours and hours of fun, problem solving and engineering.
Fun game that requires literally zero purchases. You're able to complete the game in full in a reasonable amount of time for an idler. No real drawbacks or negatives for this game for me!

Really good game, lots of progressing to do and is easy to learn quickly, all about optimizing and finding the most efficient way to earn resources. 

and to majority of people leaving a bad review, most of yall clearly just don't like idle games or barely played it. the games actually fun and you can OPTIONALLY support the creator, and still progress without having to in the first place. if you don't like idle games then don't play it, but its not an excuse to leave a bad review
It is a fun experience.  I enjoyed everything but the coding.  I never really got the coding.  Otherwise, it is fun and challenging enough to warrant a play through.
Great little optimization game. Good pacing, definite variety in challenges.
UI could use a bit of QOL fixes, but the content and theme are great fun regardless.

I've completed this game at 55 hours. Used portal about 5x. It becomes very quick towards the end game. 

Don't get me wrong though, this game is not easy, albeit it is complicated and worth it.

Addictive enough to further ruin my sleep schedule.

Building node graphs is more involved than pretty much the majority of idle games you can find, especially if you engage in micromanaging file creation with some of the tools the game gives you later on (decompiler, ripper, demuxer, etc...).

Going for the last achievements is a little misleading though. I thought I had to buy every optimization, but for some reason the achievement triggers if you buy *at least one level of each optimization\*. I'm not complaining too much though, but this could be made a bit more clear.

The upcoming 2.0 update looks really good can't wait for it to drop [strike]and completely drop my productivity[/strike] üëÄ
Didn't expect to love this game as much as I do, this is the kind of game I can just wind down with. Overall amazing game would recommend to my friends if they existed
It's easy to pick up and, unlike most incremental games, progress doesn't seem to hit artificial walls. Couple that with its clear, simple graphics and I'm left with only positives to say for this.

Had tons of fun first jumping into this game and learning all the new nodes you can unlock to make more stacks more efficient. The progression in this game is near solid, minus the optimization points being a bit slow compared to everything else. The need to make your stacks of nodes better and better kept me coming back. I enjoyed looking at the achievements at the start and most of them making no sense and then I gradually unlocked what was needed to finish them granting me a few ah-ha moments. The polish of the node design, font, effects was very nice. Some colors were too close to others along with the shapes so when diving into a new piece (coding, AGI for some examples) it became somewhat confusing. Overall for a free game this is one of the best in this category IMHO. There are some minor annoyances as I mentioned but I can see the path they are headed and hope more is added so I can enter the portal once more and finally max out all my hardware nodes.

This game gives me both the urge to organize my room as well and disassemble my computer because it's slower than a moldy baked potato. This game has more consistency than my life.

Anyways, good game.
this game was fantastic for late night and movie on the second screen type. Love it.

If you‚Äôre on the fence about downloading it, just do it. The download is small, and once you start, you‚Äôll be hungry for more.

I absolutely NEEDED to reach the end of the game and create a fully-developed lab, and the more I played, the more I wanted to keep playing. If you are autistic, as well, and enjoy logistic systems, then this game will probably entrance you as it did me.

This is a nice and relaxing game with good music and a simple, yet fun gameplay.
after 88 hours of playing this game I unlocked the last achievement. Overall I'd say it was a really fun and addictive game.
While seemingly simple, it is super fun to play and to sit back and watch the numbers go up after renovating and reordering your designs
this game is perfect for people with ocd, tryna get that organize and symmetry is something.

fun and free game.
It has a unique premise and executes it well, game does slow down at points but there are many options to min/max production to speed the game up.
The managing of resources is on-par with satisfactory but there is no grind and it's less tedious to set things up.
There is little reason to try this out unless you want to see 2.0 before then!

Fantastic idle game that lets me create automations by connecting different components together.  The game is one of the better idle games, because it does not take a lot of time to reach the endgame nor get all the achievements.  The interface is clean and simple too.
fun game to dedicate my existence to for a night.

ive played this game more than your fave possibly so just give it a try its not a hard game if you read things but its treal and erra so dont give up its an amzing game btw 484 hours played at the time of post

It‚Äôs an awesome game ‚Äî actually, it‚Äôs an excellent tool for learning networks and computer architecture. If you're interested in this field, you‚Äôre going to play this game a lot. It‚Äôs one of the best.

What a game, especially for free.

I am not usually a fan of idlers as I find them a little boring. But, this game fits my interests and has much more depth than a usual idle clicker, and was fun from start to finish.

I do however wish the game was a little more complicated. Maybe lean more into requiring optimization to be more important. Instead of having modules auto balance to input, maybe have a hard input cap on modules so you have to figure out the proper ratio of modules to consume a given output of items, sort of factorio like. Also, allocators need finer controls, otherwise you end up having to stack lots to achieve say a 100:1 ratio, whereas if you had decimal granularity you could  handle it with one or two allocators.
Excellent game! Wish there was more customization for the wires, but it's a simple, free game that is enjoyable.
I really like these type of automation games, Upload Labs is particular is very relaxing. The music is also much better then I expected.

Very good game,
Interesting and very nice noodles you get to make with all the connections

the pay content is not a must, it is much better after QoL update, pending for the 2.0!
it is a nice game given that it is FREE, could help you let the time pass faster
this game was so good i loved it very much but sometimes its make me confused but for overall this game its so good compare to how much you have to download
I think people are angry that this is an idle game because it could have been so much more... Still a good idle game as it is
Very simple yet very complex idle game which i loved a lot
Really interesting and addictive game! Also teaches a few general ideas of coding.
it is a fun game that has no end techniliy but if you like steam achivement hunting you would like this game

i think this game is very well made and very worth playing, soundtrack is also quite nice, also the sounds in the background do relax you. Overall i think that Upload labs is a game, very worth playing
Very good idle game for when you're bored or doing other things
Pretty fun time killer that's equally addictive as games like Factorio or Satisfactory
Its kinda cool ya just sit there and do different things like stare at the in game stock market
upload, downloadl a computer in a computer. nice easy game.
very addicting and crypto
Didn't expect it to be so fun. Would have been fine with paying a few bucks for this.

Surprisingly good game, I really enjoy(ed) it. It gets a bit bland, while waiting for research points to trickle in, but its a perfect game to just have running in the background while doing something else, occasionally checking in on it. 

Would recommend - 8/10
It's a really great game that keeps you thinking and surprisingly well done for a free game, I really enjoyed it
Would like to see a little more evolution in gameplay, but fun game
Fun game, you might wanna prepare yourself to do some factorio type optimization tho. Would reccomend
If you love using your brain, yes, this is THE game for you. Its a big number go up game that takes an understanding of pathing and optimizations then rewards you. Best dopamine I've had in a while.

Very good base game, every update is very good.
Alot of options to do xD
this game even thought it is simple, it is pretty cool and relaxing

Honestly I really like it as someone who is getting into coding. I do still have to learn some of the processes. I would expand on the knowledge book for more information. Overall 9/10 and can only get better from here.
This idle game is just so unique compared to others and some how manages to keep my attention despite being an idle, even though I usually get bored while playing idle games.

Thinking
A addicted idle game, real fun to see the number going by level uping the componeunt.

Just not sure why I cant get the final achievement.
A very fun and entertaining game for when you are bored, i'm definitely going to be spending some hours in this
Fun free to play game simple and easy. Cant wait for more updates!

I love this game, it's so addicting.
I kept this game running overnights and still having fun.
I don't usually review games, but from what I have played, this game is phenomenal.

A fairly worthwhile game that has a fair amount of features to keep a lot of people entertained for a good while, but do keep in mind that this game below the surface is fairly repetitive as when getting something new to upload, that it is always gonna be better than the previous version.  All in all, this game is a fair game to either have in the background, make stuff that looks complicated to pretend to be smarter than you are, or to just have just in case (and it's free!).
it is fun and easy to play. perfect for when you feel like there is nothing to do
great little Idle game, especially if you like networking/computer stuff

Upload Labs is a free-to-play simulation and automation game that focuses on building, optimizing, and managing data-processing systems. It blends puzzle-like logic with resource management, offering a satisfying experience for players who enjoy designing efficient workflows rather than engaging in action-heavy gameplay.
Great game to throw on a second monitor while doing other tasks. Plus its free
Great game to just relax in, just relax and let the game take you away.
Honestly a very chill and enjoyable simulator. It simulates basically how computer networks work and then teaches you organization and resource management skills.

negative.review: Was fun starting out, but felt very repetitive to me after some time.

The game has a very slow start and does not to have any interesting challenges. From peeking into endgame footage, it seems the is no greater strategy, only placing easy automation chains. Maybe someone will find that appealing, but I'd rather either play an idle game with better pacing or one with harder automation challenges,

Game feels very anti-fun in a lot of places
1. Having a diverse set of files that you work with w/ text, images, etc, absolutely kills your income and progress. You have to continuously stick to one single file type, whichever one is the most recent. This makes it so diversifying your income is punished and the game expects you to automate one single product and nothing else.
2. Node limit (?????). I don't get this. Upload/download speed and CPU power etc are already key limits. Why punish the player for wanting to have fun. It makes it so even if you ACCEPT the drastically slower progress just for the sake of having some damn variety, it will physically not let you.
3. In usual fashion, grindy and progress starts to slow to a crawl. F2P incremental games typically have this issue so you know what to expect.

It's an incremental game with nothing that really brings it up above the rest of the pack.  It LOOKS like it has something to do with programming, but it's JUST looks.  You can move individual tasks around the table, but ultimately, you get one of every input and there's one optimal way to output it.  There's no creativity here, you just take the download to the file type, then do whatever processing you have available to you, then output for money.  When you get enough money, you push the button to spend the money buying something that makes it go faster so you get more money faster.  

After pushing through for a few hours, the only new curveball they throw is a "hacking" system where it's just waiting for you to gain enough hacker XP to level up hacking so you can hack something harder for more hacking XP.  Basically, the same pig with a new shade of lipstick.

I've played a few other incremental games that tried to do more with the concept, but this is just a basic "wait for number to get big enough so you're allowed to push the button" game.  I guess it distracted me and it's free, so it's not that bad, but... meh...

The game seems to fight against fun at every corner, it's more optimal to focus on one thing than actually making big cool flowcharts with lots of different moving parts
You just make your upgrade pipeline, stick the highest value file in and that's it.
try to do anything more interesting and it just loses you money
Granted, I've not gotten *that* far through the game, but the gameplay loop is very samey, I know it's a free idle game, but I just wish it was a little more flexible with what you could do, rather than punishing you for makling a big cool flowchart.

Needs more tooltips when trying to workout connections. Says you placed some hacking nodes after portal even thou it is blank. I hope this game deals with some more basic explaining and can be a great game. Looking forward for updates but in current state I do not want to waste time on figuring out how it works.
Does not sync well with other devices.  It does sync, but you have to do it manually, and this can lead to loss of premium currency.

Somehow you guys failed to make an actual working average/s percentage. The game does not even have progression the 90% of the time.
And, by the way, how the fuck do you guys have the balls, THE BALLS, to put pay2win in a game. Ok, its free, ok. But mf, HOW, HOWWW

Free game, why not? What people don't realize is that time is money, even if the game is free.

Overall, good game. Let's you work out the brain if you are fine tuning input values/resources. My biggest beef is that it lacks a proper tutorial where new node outputs would be properly explained.

Some may say, what would you expect from free game? But like all things, "free" comes with caveat. In this case, I am not getting my hours back for playing it.

This game is not in early access, so a lack of a proper tutorial is not excusable at this point. So if you don't mind, just going to shop around and pay for an actual working game.

P.S.: I write maybe 1 review per 10 games I play. My reviews are often positive. Pause and think what that means when someone who doesn't go out of their way to write a review, writes a bad one.

Not sure where the positive reviews are coming from. A bit of a nonsensical concept. Downloading and uploading the same file creates value? I suppose it's a good time waster if that's what you're out to do.

The concept of the game is pretty cool. However, there is a distinct lack of explanations and highlights, making it very tedious to find new unlocks and to find out what setups are efficient - too tedious for me. However, if you are the type of player who enjoys building different setups and check what's more efficient, this might be the game for you.
Game is good but constantly crashes in the end game, it's almost unbearable trying to complete the achievements because of the crashing.

All and all it's a good idle game with decent flow and progress.

That level 50 optimization achievement "Back-end Dev" is actually terrible and needs to go though. The entire game and all it's unlocks, are done around optimization 25. So basically you have 25 extra levels of grind to just sit through with no meaningful progression outside of a few % boosts which don't actually make that much of a difference in terms of the waiting game. I get now why so few people have that one achievement, but even than I'm surprised 1.5% of players sat through it.

Level 21 code interface+8.3x boost from AI = 20.3m/s optimization at Coding level 9 from portal. To go from 30 to 31 requires 53.6b points. So roughly 40min. For 1 of 20 levels. That will only get slower. This number goes up by several billion per upgrade. Yea not that "fun" I would say.

The game was a good 20ish hours up until this point though. Only down-voting because that achievement is just plain bad for people that like to 100% games.

I don't think this game is mature enough, or if it is, it is very complex and not easy for the genaral public. The interface should be tuned to allow a simpler interaction between components and the tasks should become a bit less repetitive ie rather than all files have download x type-> action -> upload -> money -- to have a few different system components etc.

This is designed to drive you towards buying tokens. the game grinds to a halt and things that should or could improve your stacks either make them worse or do nothing. Often speeds just cap. like 30m/s research is horrendous when you need tillions to unlock new stuff. money is straight forward and is the only thing that actually makes sense to when increasing income. Tokens... 90% is just waiting around for them to pop up occasionally. Very occasionally. Yes, you can do the achievements and requests, but those quickly become painfully slow. Not a fan of games that make you spend hours with no progress.

Well.... 

TLDR: 
[ + ] Fun concept as the base of the game but....
[ - ] falls short really fast by F2P need to drive players into monetization by absurd grind
[ - ] Misleading store page description

non-TLDR:
[ + ] nice "light" factory game concept as the base for the game, gave vibe of shapez games where no need to worry with survival/resources/complex crafting, just put thing A together with thing B and get thing C

[ - ] game has active game play for about 30 minutes, after that it comes to a stop with nothing left to do and you need to let it run in background to accumulate "funds" for next progression steps, and after each cycle the wait gets longer to the point that out of 35h i have in it at the review moment, i had interacted with the game only for a few hours, rest was it sitting running overnight/in the background, so essentially it is idler game, 
and it seems that only other way reduce wait part are dlc`s which after looking at them for a second is unfortunately yet another free-to-play -> pay-to-enjoy game slop in my opinion

[ - ] and last my main issue with it and why i am flagging review as negative is simply false advertising. literally go hit ctrl+f in the browser for this games store page and type "idle", 
literally not a single mention on this games steam page at the moment of this review, only one user-defined tag and user reviews (thank god steam has this features), if it would be upfront about the fact that it is F2P idler game i would had no issues with it and frankly wouldn't even bother downloading it

A fun cookie clicker with factory elements and a gross mobile-esque monitization model looming over it's shoulder. 
My message to the devs: Take your drip-fed microtransaction BS back to the app store, and let me just buy the game once without worrying about how you have molested the game's balance to push me into giving you endless amounts of money. 

I don't play mobile games for this exact reason, and I suggest you avoid this game if you feel the same.

I like the game. 
But there are a few things I wish would be addressed:
1)if you click a input or output there is no way of unlicking the link. 
2)A better description of what each item does. Like how the allocator works and so on.
3)A way to save a game. I know games like this have a feature that will let you start over but with improved time. 

Please fix bugs and make better,.

Extremely interesting concept, but the fact that genuinely useful items and stuff that is necessary to achieve anywhere near optimal production is locked behind a currency that you can only realistically get a finite amount of without paying real money is unfair and ridiculous

LOVE THE GAME COOL CONCEPT BUT..... the first processor unlock causes the entire game to crash so i wish i could play m ore of it but the darn thing crashes everytime i buy the proscessor unlock please fix so i can keep playing!

It's a Idle games masked as a factory builder, has some depth (there is a tiny learning curve later when you start with programming). The network has a bottleneck which means having veriety has no meaning if you want to maximize your profit. 

I won't spend much time on this game, as you can bypass the paywall by simply editing your save and the idle part is gets tedious very quickly, rendering progress useless. 
I'm only playing around to see what is offered, I like the concept...

I played until "programming" was unlocked because I had some hope that there was some actual programming in it, but no, it's just more of the same. I guess it's just not my cup of tea. 

There are some bugs in the interface that makes it really annoying to play, prob from being originally a mobile game. Also there are too many currencies that don't really fit together, so you get many separate systems that don't really talk to each other.

UI is poorly designed (connection lines cross underneath panels), it's a flowchart designer's nightmare.

What each new panel does is unclear, some panels have no final connection to use or sell the item. 

29 minutes and I'm done
It's an interesting Idle game but still an idle game. You could go do something productive instead of getting distracted by this.

Disclaimer at the end of review where I still kinda recommend the game.

I was enjoying it, until I got to "coding"...
You get float, int, Bool and char and you need to combine these in various different ways to make upgrades... How do you combine them? Well... I have no idea.
I've tried googling it, I've tried doing random ones. I can't work it out.
I know you can use the same one twice, so that makes trial and error take a bit longer.

It feels really dumb to have you know how to code to play the game... It's an idle game... gimme a break here, yeah?

So I don't pass the IQ test to play the game, that's my main issue with it.

Other issues include that it's just a complicated mess... I was enjoying sorting it out until I realised there's a prestige mechanic... So you have to spend ages having a nice clean system, putting things together. Which takes quite a long time I'll add... And then you have to... do it again? and again? and again?
That's not even remotely enjoyable.

This is an incremental game, but I wouldn't call it an idle game. Because you have to do a lot to get the numbers to go up.
There's parts of it where it is essentially just leave it going while you sleep. (Which is why I'm at 9 hours. I don't sleep very long sadly.) Which is fine, it's an idle game with a lot of interaction. I'm okay with that...
But then you also have to spend ages sorting everything out, then working out what combines with what. In the coding area...
If the game had a guide to the coding within the game... I wouldn't be so negative on it. Overall, I've enjoyed most of the time I've spent on this.
But this part of the game really does ruin it for me. Because it feels like there's this weird external knowledge barrier on continuation, and the game doesn't tell you how to play it.
It'd be like if a game suddenly started speaking French, and just expected you to know how to speak French. Or if Le r√©dacteur du commentaire s'est soudainement mis √† √©crire en fran√ßais et s'attendait simplement √† ce que vous suiviez le rythme. (I used google translate, this is probably gibberish. Sorry. I cannot speak enough french to get by. XD)

The game does have a guide, what it really should have done is had a link to a bit in the guide where it tells you what the codes are, or said in the tooltip "Check the guide for details."
But all it does say in the guide is "Provides code speed based on your contribution level. Contribution level can be upgraded by inserting contribution" Which is a very weird sentence.
Honestly... I think even if the coding were better explained, I'd still recommend against the game... But less harshly. The prestige mechanic does kill it a bit.

It's free though, so even though I recommend against it.... I still recommend you try it for yourself. Because you don't have anything to lose if you don't like it, and chances are you'll enjoy it more than I did if this is the kind of game for you.
Steam asks if I would recommend this game to other players, and my brain takes that literal... I wouldn't... I'd never be in conversation and say "Oh, you should try Upload labs." But here, on this review... Yeah, give it a go, find out for yourself. Good luck. ^_^

needs work as i had a line stuck at the end of my pointer and could not deselect, even after making the connection.
tutorial was telling me to then click on bin but the screen just scrolled down and down and down and the bin was not clickable due to the line still connected to the pointer.

i got past this eventually but then something new unlocked and it uses money generated to create clock speed or something. this stopped my earnings so i removed it and returned all connections to return to earnings again, yet the game acted as if i had removed nothing and i was still earning nothing to collect. i removed all connections and tried reconnecting and still nothing. game effectively broken.

i tried turning it off and turning it on again and lo and behold it did fuck all. uninstalled top make space for a game designed with some imagination instead

[h1] This review is coming from someone with 1069+ hours in idle/clicker/incremental games.[/h1]

Earlier games in the genre actually had intrigue and things to say, but at some point society utterly collapsed and now devs are playing the skinner box numbers go up simulator completely straight. The the addictive part of gameplay without the gameplay.

As for the actual game? I'll be real, even by Idle game standards this is pretty whatever.
The flowchart angle on paper could leave room for nuanced progression, but the reality is that people min-max the fun out of their games for the sake of efficiency, and this game barely has any fun to begin with.

The progression is slow, and there is no offline progression like most games do to front-load the dopamine spike that gets players engaged for 5 minutes before closing again. If players aim is efficiency and big numbers, their best bet is to have the game open at all times. So if your gameplay loop demands constant computing power from players machines, it better justify itself. And it really doesn't. It takes extremely low effort to make a game like this and them having the gall to expect people to pay for DLC for a game you don't actually playing 90% of the time is absurd.

I'm not sure if it's un-cohesive or too cohesive, I'm just bored. it is surprisingly linear in practice than the Steam page would suggest. If you are deadset on a game like this; there are dozens out there for the very same price of [b]FREE[/b] that are more worth your time.

There's zero depth to this game. I'm an hour in and bored out of my mind.I fail to see how there's any kind of optimization I'm supposed to do. Everything is 1:1, in and out. All I do is sit and watch. How is that fun?

idk what its trying to do here, but it should have been a sandbox game with a different plot so to say. the scalability of things are just off when all you need to do is have one branch of a steady flow, the rest is just weird side quest in a way. im jsut saying the concept of the game was i cool idea but it just doesnt seem playable unless you wanna be a smart*** and jsut wanna look cool by adding more nodes for no reason. 

in short your not optimizing, the concept of the game was really inticing, but the delievery of progression and even the way its played is plain day boring and useless.
Hard to use the blueprints when you need to completely delete then make a new one. I wish there was an update button of some kind.
Too long idle. Too much work optimizing. Too few returns. Too lazy to optimize.
Not only is this a bad game, its also not a well-made game, AND its pay-to-win.  Yikes.

Let me be clear. This is NOT an automation game. It is an idle game like cookie clicker very loosely disguised as a factory game. You have one of each production unit. That means you cannot scale up at all. You literally are just waiting to click the upgrade button that increases your income by 100% over and over and over. Tier up just increases money, no nuance. The free to play is to lure in people to pay for boosts etc. Terrible and honestly disgusting design.

This game has potential, but it lacks the ability to do "smart" things.  In the end, the best way to make money is to use the best result out of one thing and remove everything else, which is not what you want from an automation game.  

You can code and hack, but it does not lead to anything usefull money wise.

Went up to unlock everything, and got nothing in return...  I found no way to complete the game.

All in all, it's FREE!!!, so try it for yourself and figure out if it's something you like.

Maybe it's because I don't like idle games but, locking you out of optimizing your system behind 200 points that I couldn't get even after hour of playing, making the unlock system more boring than it has to be, transfer rates being strangely random AND inserting right in the game itself micro transactions disguised as a "support for the dev", doesn't really make me want to keep playing. Not sure about others but I don't feel inclined on keep playing this.

The games setup and overall flow is good. Unlike most idle games that have a massive burst of progress and then slow down to a crawl, making you prestige over and over again, Upload labs managed to keep my interest by having more and more mechanics, upgrade paths and things to do. I spent a fair bit of time in organizing everything and setting up proper ratios to make it as efficient as possible. Even without paying I was able to progress a fair bit and get to the portals (which is the prestige mechanic) in a couple of hours.
That is where the problems started. The game gives us NO indication that the portals are the version of prestige in this game. It told me it will make my components 100% more efficient, something that a lot of other upgrades state, and proceeded to reset my progress. I didn't even have time to save schematics for the node groups I was using for each file type. It removed any sense of familiarity and ownership I had over the system I'd built. I no longer wanted to invest time into making it more efficient, more organized, better built. I simply wanted to click the button and make number go up since it will reset anyways.
Which brings me to the next issue. The schematics system sucks. It doesn't store the connections between the nodes. It simply stores the node types and their relative positions. If your schematic had 10 nodes, you have to hook them up manually every single time. This makes resetting to prestige extremely annoying as you have to manually go through the links again.
The game also lacks polish overall. Using the selection tool to select multiple nodes, does not select node groups that you have already created, so if you move your whole system lets say upwards to create more space below, you have to manually set up your node groups again. In the hacking nodes, where you have a limited amount of time to breach them via attack nodes, the hacks can fail if you are playing the game in fast forward but pass if you're playing them at nomal speed if the time is close to running out.
Overall, 6/10. Good game, but will not recommend investing your time into it.

As the game progressed, I started to realize how dumb things were getting.

The pipelines started to make no sense in regards to compression, checksums, virus scanning, "enhancing". 

It seemed to get progressively dumber as you get more processes unlocked.

Market mechanics made no sense.  I can sell one or billons of crypto and crash the market regardless.

The game's mechanics were not balanced, Seemed to me the most optimal money generation was focusing minimal cpu into the biggest task(progams in my case)  processing queue and the smallest (text files)  towards resarch and sell the rest of the cpu usages.   Because you end up bottlenecked by ISP speeds and research speeds. 
The research bottleneck required me to use 4 ratio tasks 9:9:9:1 to put the max files into research without  accumulation and dump the rest of the worthless text files for insignificant cash.

Audio, images, video...ignored waste of time and money to bother with.  Only the chunkiest and smallest  downloads mattered.

I think the part that got to me was the concept of compression and "enhancement" (ie decompression)

compression would reduce filesize and value by 4.
enhancement would increase filesize and value by 4. (and you can see why I called it "decompression")

so what exactly are we enhancing in a text file?  or a program.  it makes no sense.  I added "enhancement" to text files to increase their value.  whut?  did it insert make pretend research text like a BS LLM?

We can do a checksum after modifying files with the anti virus processes. and it can fail that checksum, and we go back and redownload the same file that magically no longer has a virus?
what?

wouldn't it make more sense to have to download compressed files, and then decompress them, do crc checks, work on them, then make a new  crc, and recompress before uploading them back up ,

so yea, the pipeline is goofy.  It is  an example of stupidification of games lately.  Like one game I played not to long ago that treated ebony as an ore.  I wanted to slap the developer. People would make arguments like "its a science fiction game" or "its beta"  "It's early access"

no.....it's stupid.  And kids will play these games and learn and believe that ebony, a wood, is an ore.

This game, like the movie "hackers".  It is just a dumb form of short lived entertainment full of internet terminology mumbo jumbo. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bmz67ErIRa4

And this game does not allow you to be idle  in this idle game considering the  crypto market design that requires you to sit and wait for the RNG market to go high and click the sell button.


in a nutshell, 9 hours in (played it last night for too long)    Take my advice, don't bother. Even free, this is just a waste of time.

There are smarter idle games that may  actually teach you something new like "Cell to Singularity"
Nice game, but in case of unexpected shutdown all of the progress is lost. Sad.

This is not a good game. The numbers gets incrementally bigger, which is addictive, but it is about the only good thing about it. The sound design is horrible. Nothing is explained. Why does putting files in a server make money? Why does the coding interfaces have inputs that match no other node? There is a skill tree, but there are no choices. It is so linear that making me click it to progress, seems like filler. Starting over and placing nodes is fun the first couple of times, but it is very fiddly, and blueprints does not help until everything is unlocked. The prestige mechanism is slow and lacklustre. Also, from the get go, you can pay to buy premium currency and permanent boosts, which in my opinion, makes this game not free to play.

It's mildly entertaining, but quickly becomes a very dull grind that doesn't actually provide speed up/relief easily.

You'll get a few hours out of it before you're bored of the grind.

interesting concept, lackluster middle ground.

Looked cool on the store page pictures, but turned out to be just a huge grindfest idle game where most of the time you are just waiting for the numbers to go up.

Nothing wrong with that at face value, but the issue is that unlocking most of the cool stuff on the pictures requires A LOT of waiting, and there's not really any interesting decisions to make regarding how you set up nodes. For the time I played, there was really just one option to do anything, so the node system is basically underutilized.

There's also nothing to really do while waiting for the numbers to go up.

Naturally, there's also pay-to-win skips for real money. I get that this is a free game, but p2w is not how games should me monetized in my opinion. Even if it "doesn't harm anymore" since it's a singleplayer game (a dumb argument to begin with), it still is designed to waste your time so you'd give in and spend money on it, it's not designed to be a good game that you don't mind sending some money on.

Its a weird mix between idler and automation, but it simply requires you to keep the whole thing open the whole time and lure you in for boosts (with different levels) 
Unless you plan to be 100% f2p I cannot recommend this game and I got bored from the f2p loop
This is an idle game that tries to convince you it's an automation game. Just mindless clicking on upgrades. You can't scale the factory or optimize it

Pros:
-Free
-Fun factory-conveyor belt gameplay

Cons
-It has micro-transactions in form of Booster-pack DLCs, and an ever-increasingly tediousness.
-Control are awkward

Verdict: 2/5

Comment: 
Whether you consider DLCs as "donations to support developers", "the real price tag of an otherwise free-game", the gameplay has strong focus on the same old Pay-to-win formula that keep nudging you toward losing to your shopping impulse. It is fun at first, until it becomes tedious due to being constantly bottleneck by scarce tokens.

Honestly, developer should just sell this game normally instead of opting for the formula of a free-to-play game that creates the problem to sell the solutions.

It took me just under 20 hours to complete the research tree and run out of upgrades to buy.
I think this game has potential but it misses in some key areas.

[list]
  [*]Every new crafting method you unlock makes everything that came before it obsolete even without upgrades. The only strategy is to put all your resources into creating the latest thing you unlocked.

  [*]Hacking and programming are completely separate and don't interact with the other core mechanics whatsoever, aside from two or three boring multiplier upgrades and a single boost node.

  [*]You can't expand horizontally like you would in a factory builder, because you're hard-capped by your 1-2 network nodes and single CPU+GPU nodes. It's never better to split your resources over multiple generators.

  [*]Resetting is tedious even with schematics, because you need to unlock the nodes you had on your previous prestige before the schematic will create them. You end up rebuilding from scratch either way.

  [*]The reset system only gives you boring resource multipliers. Huge missed opportunity for a skill tree or something that could fix the way that mechanics become obsolete so fast.

  [*]Tedious micromanagement. You're incentivized to never split your resources which means you have to manually disconnect and reconnect your nodes whenever you want to switch file types or outputs.

  [*]Not very good for idle play since progression is so heavily tied to swapping to the next tier of file generation.
[/list]

I saw some people (with less than two hours played) whining about the microtransactions. You can pretty much ignore those reviews. You unlock more ways to get tokens later into the game and I never found myself lacking them without spending a dime.

As it stands now, I think the game is just a bit too directionless and doesn't really capture the satisfaction of building a nice factory or progressing in an idle game. I think this game could be good with updates and reworks.

Also, for stuff like IDE and the various splitter, please let me input the ratio in weight, they are basically useless currently as they can only output 1:9 to 9:1, this triggers my OCD for perfect ratio, I can only get a rough ratio with these, granted it is like a 10% inefficiency but it is really annoying

It uses so much resources, my pc is trying to liftoff. What is it doing with it? miner?

Not sure what to think so far. My biggest issue is that rn atleast the game has like no horizontal scaling. Since your downlaoders and uploaders are not limited instead of building new production lines you just build one that outputs more. 
I do believe the game wants you to think that you are limited by other ressources but you rarely are. 

Example. Why would you ever build 2 text downloader workflows when you could just have one that does the same as 2 ? 
Why would you ever want to have productionlines for different file types when you could just do the most profitable one ? 

I quickly realized the game wants to be more of an idle game, however this also doesnt really work out cause while offline you dont get money, you just get time speed up. So instead of coming back, buying new upgrades and redesiging your most proftibale workflow you first need to sit there and wait. 

Its an odd game so far. Will keep playing tho to see where it leads. Oh also 

no steam achievements .... why :c

I strongly advise against playing Upload Labs or purchasing any of its DLCs. There‚Äôs a critical, game-breaking bug tied to the portal node that can completely erase your entire design without warning. I personally lost over 20 hours of work due to this issue and was reset to nothing. It‚Äôs unacceptable for a game to ship with such a destructive flaw, especially without any safeguards or alerts. Until this is addressed, I cannot recommend this game in any capacity. The developer needs to take responsibility and fix this immediately.

Sick idea for a game, and some genuinely cool ideas for nodes and the purpose for connecting them. Absolutely abysmal execution. I can‚Äôt even comprehend how you built such a solid foundation and then tripped over the most basic problems.
It's not proper PC port,I didn‚Äôt even have to check to know it was originally a mobile game.They didn‚Äôt even bother removing the ‚Äúwatch ad‚Äù buttons. The tutorial is dogshit, giving zero proper explanation for the first 10 minutes. You just sit there waiting for money to unlock things, without ever needing to change your starting setup. 
And when you finally unlock some interesting nodes, the game stumbles again - there‚Äôs basically no depth in how you can actually optimize or manage the system. After about an hour, you hit a plateau where you just wait for money again, because it's a fucking mobile game, and you have to leave. 
The dev clearly never worked with node-based systems before, controls are clunky, and the alignment is maddening. Why the fuck can I drag only one control point manage connections and where they go from one node to other. 
Pay2Play is cringe as fuck, ‚Äúsubscribe‚Äù to receive coins every day for unlocking new nodes.

In short, I sure hope someone takes this idea and makes a proper game out of it.

I had some fun with this but ultimately this is a wholly a mobile idle game, not an automation title.
To elaborate on what I mean by that: here's the gameplay loop.
[list]
[*] You get 1 CPU, 1 GPU, and 1 upload node (2 UN's via an upgrade). You use these to upload file types and mine cryptocurrency for money. Every upgrade to these using said money is a 100% boost in efficiency flat. With no more of these nodes available, there is no scaling. Upgrading one of them bottlenecks the others, you must then upgrade the others.
[*] There are 6 file types. They all function exactly the same, they just are a larger size in bytes to upload/download. You start with text and upload until you get the money to unlock the next file type, repeat all 6 types,
[*] You unlock extra 'refinements' you can do to the file type such as virus scanning to increase its value. The refinements are the same for every file type, operate in the same order.
[*] You unlock hacking which allows you to get temporary upgrades to increase the speed at which everything moves, but requires you to create an idle loop of increasingly expensive hacking points with no scaling.
[*] You unlock coding, which works exactly the same as hacking and unlocks upgrades for the current iteration you're on.
[*] Eventually your progress slows and fails until you 'enter the portal' which gives some multiplicative upgrades and resets everything (think AdVenture Capitalist prestige).
[*] Restart but w/ the multiplicative upgrades you unlocked.
[*] Repeat until 100% or bored.
[/list]
Now there are some important extra notes to make about this that make me go from "decent free idle" to "no".
[list]
[*] Permanent upgrades are either farmed 5 at a time through rng popups, 20-25 from idle quantity achievements, or hacking popups (increasingly difficult). [b]Or[/b] you can buy $4 daily token option to skip the grind. A lot of the permanent upgrades are necessary for sanity (ex: auto-collectors)
[*] These tokens are also used to get 2x production boosts that last for a few minutes. [b][i]Or[/i][/b] you can pay [i]$10[/i] to make them permanent. Tthis will just linearly scale everything 2x in an idle game.
[*] [b][i]This game does not have offline progression.[/i][/b] When you are offline, nothing happens. When you log back on, based on how long you were offline, you earn up to 600 seconds of "boost time" where everything goes at 5x speed. You can use tokens to permanently increase the rate of accumulation or the amount by 10%. [b][i][u]Or[/u][/i][/b] you can pay $8 to earn this time while online and increase the total amount you can earn.
[*] The game is not saved locally. If for whatever reason it shuts down, so do you.
[/list]
The game is decent, but I'd rather have seen it cost a couple dollars and remove the MTX and their push on all 3 for "level up your supporter badge". I also understand why its called an automation game, but it isn't one, you just connect nodes which operate the same way for all files, with no options to scale production.

Game used to work fine, but then there was an update that made SSE4.2 a requirement, even though the minimum specs on the store page put them before it was a requirement.

On top of that, the cloud save doesn't actually sync between devices so you have to export and import the save file manually. 

Overall, it was fun while I could play it, but now with the SSE4.2 requirement I would be suspect of this game that it's not actually running something on your pc while you have the game up for the dev to make money.

progression is painfully slow even for an idle game, I couldn't stay hooked as there was almost nothing to do (also I'm very salty about the folder feature, it deleted 1k files I had on it because I put another type of file as the first input)

No victory condition, game continue forever. Each prestige level, you rebuild the same system, it's just faster now. Messy components, don't play if you have OCD. Useless documentation. Plenty of junk upgrades. Trying each component for the first time was fun. Badly designed overall. I regret paying for this and I do not recommend it.

Pretty standard idler with some graphical polish. The way it hides all the QoL stuff behind a drip feed of inconsistent tokens that requires active attention to catch felt predatory. There's a clear design intent there to drive microtransactions, and that turned me off of the game. I don't recommend this one.

the progression is to liniar and to slow,
also the game itself isnt complex enough to be intrestting to make certain descisions

This is basically a good automation game but got taken over by disguised monetization.
If they released the game like Shapez (not even Shapez 2) at full price of $10 or so, I would've brought it. But to lock progression or rather grinding time, behind paywall is not acceptable. It's free so no worries. Play as much as you want and grind away. However don't spend a penny on this as this type of idler with paid system will only incentivize further new idler games to do the same in the future.

I spent a large time un-optimally AFK, however the game finishes extremely fast. I didn't touch certain mechanics ('coding') and was able to get through very easily.

Fun for a quick thing but there's a lot better games that you can invest and spend time in optimizing

Limited and boring. There's no interesting challenge or setup or nothing to do really, just connect input to output and wait ever increasing amounts of time, that you can skip with currency. Is that even a game at this point?

Wouldn't waste my time with this opened in the background either, there are better free idler games out there

typical mobile game design, pay now / watch ads for X minutes of x32 income multipliers. super slow progression curve because of it, early you're watiting for 10+ minutes just to get the first unlock and start playing.
Was fun starting out, but felt very repetitive to me after some time.

The game has a very slow start and does not to have any interesting challenges. From peeking into endgame footage, it seems the is no greater strategy, only placing easy automation chains. Maybe someone will find that appealing, but I'd rather either play an idle game with better pacing or one with harder automation challenges,

Game feels very anti-fun in a lot of places
1. Having a diverse set of files that you work with w/ text, images, etc, absolutely kills your income and progress. You have to continuously stick to one single file type, whichever one is the most recent. This makes it so diversifying your income is punished and the game expects you to automate one single product and nothing else.
2. Node limit (?????). I don't get this. Upload/download speed and CPU power etc are already key limits. Why punish the player for wanting to have fun. It makes it so even if you ACCEPT the drastically slower progress just for the sake of having some damn variety, it will physically not let you.
3. In usual fashion, grindy and progress starts to slow to a crawl. F2P incremental games typically have this issue so you know what to expect.

It's an incremental game with nothing that really brings it up above the rest of the pack.  It LOOKS like it has something to do with programming, but it's JUST looks.  You can move individual tasks around the table, but ultimately, you get one of every input and there's one optimal way to output it.  There's no creativity here, you just take the download to the file type, then do whatever processing you have available to you, then output for money.  When you get enough money, you push the button to spend the money buying something that makes it go faster so you get more money faster.  

After pushing through for a few hours, the only new curveball they throw is a "hacking" system where it's just waiting for you to gain enough hacker XP to level up hacking so you can hack something harder for more hacking XP.  Basically, the same pig with a new shade of lipstick.

I've played a few other incremental games that tried to do more with the concept, but this is just a basic "wait for number to get big enough so you're allowed to push the button" game.  I guess it distracted me and it's free, so it's not that bad, but... meh...

The game seems to fight against fun at every corner, it's more optimal to focus on one thing than actually making big cool flowcharts with lots of different moving parts
You just make your upgrade pipeline, stick the highest value file in and that's it.
try to do anything more interesting and it just loses you money
Granted, I've not gotten *that* far through the game, but the gameplay loop is very samey, I know it's a free idle game, but I just wish it was a little more flexible with what you could do, rather than punishing you for makling a big cool flowchart.

Needs more tooltips when trying to workout connections. Says you placed some hacking nodes after portal even thou it is blank. I hope this game deals with some more basic explaining and can be a great game. Looking forward for updates but in current state I do not want to waste time on figuring out how it works.
Does not sync well with other devices.  It does sync, but you have to do it manually, and this can lead to loss of premium currency.

Somehow you guys failed to make an actual working average/s percentage. The game does not even have progression the 90% of the time.
And, by the way, how the fuck do you guys have the balls, THE BALLS, to put pay2win in a game. Ok, its free, ok. But mf, HOW, HOWWW

Free game, why not? What people don't realize is that time is money, even if the game is free.

Overall, good game. Let's you work out the brain if you are fine tuning input values/resources. My biggest beef is that it lacks a proper tutorial where new node outputs would be properly explained.

Some may say, what would you expect from free game? But like all things, "free" comes with caveat. In this case, I am not getting my hours back for playing it.

This game is not in early access, so a lack of a proper tutorial is not excusable at this point. So if you don't mind, just going to shop around and pay for an actual working game.

P.S.: I write maybe 1 review per 10 games I play. My reviews are often positive. Pause and think what that means when someone who doesn't go out of their way to write a review, writes a bad one.

Not sure where the positive reviews are coming from. A bit of a nonsensical concept. Downloading and uploading the same file creates value? I suppose it's a good time waster if that's what you're out to do.

The concept of the game is pretty cool. However, there is a distinct lack of explanations and highlights, making it very tedious to find new unlocks and to find out what setups are efficient - too tedious for me. However, if you are the type of player who enjoys building different setups and check what's more efficient, this might be the game for you.
Game is good but constantly crashes in the end game, it's almost unbearable trying to complete the achievements because of the crashing.

All and all it's a good idle game with decent flow and progress.

That level 50 optimization achievement "Back-end Dev" is actually terrible and needs to go though. The entire game and all it's unlocks, are done around optimization 25. So basically you have 25 extra levels of grind to just sit through with no meaningful progression outside of a few % boosts which don't actually make that much of a difference in terms of the waiting game. I get now why so few people have that one achievement, but even than I'm surprised 1.5% of players sat through it.

Level 21 code interface+8.3x boost from AI = 20.3m/s optimization at Coding level 9 from portal. To go from 30 to 31 requires 53.6b points. So roughly 40min. For 1 of 20 levels. That will only get slower. This number goes up by several billion per upgrade. Yea not that "fun" I would say.

The game was a good 20ish hours up until this point though. Only down-voting because that achievement is just plain bad for people that like to 100% games.

I don't think this game is mature enough, or if it is, it is very complex and not easy for the genaral public. The interface should be tuned to allow a simpler interaction between components and the tasks should become a bit less repetitive ie rather than all files have download x type-> action -> upload -> money -- to have a few different system components etc.

This is designed to drive you towards buying tokens. the game grinds to a halt and things that should or could improve your stacks either make them worse or do nothing. Often speeds just cap. like 30m/s research is horrendous when you need tillions to unlock new stuff. money is straight forward and is the only thing that actually makes sense to when increasing income. Tokens... 90% is just waiting around for them to pop up occasionally. Very occasionally. Yes, you can do the achievements and requests, but those quickly become painfully slow. Not a fan of games that make you spend hours with no progress.

Well.... 

TLDR: 
[ + ] Fun concept as the base of the game but....
[ - ] falls short really fast by F2P need to drive players into monetization by absurd grind
[ - ] Misleading store page description

non-TLDR:
[ + ] nice "light" factory game concept as the base for the game, gave vibe of shapez games where no need to worry with survival/resources/complex crafting, just put thing A together with thing B and get thing C

[ - ] game has active game play for about 30 minutes, after that it comes to a stop with nothing left to do and you need to let it run in background to accumulate "funds" for next progression steps, and after each cycle the wait gets longer to the point that out of 35h i have in it at the review moment, i had interacted with the game only for a few hours, rest was it sitting running overnight/in the background, so essentially it is idler game, 
and it seems that only other way reduce wait part are dlc`s which after looking at them for a second is unfortunately yet another free-to-play -> pay-to-enjoy game slop in my opinion

[ - ] and last my main issue with it and why i am flagging review as negative is simply false advertising. literally go hit ctrl+f in the browser for this games store page and type "idle", 
literally not a single mention on this games steam page at the moment of this review, only one user-defined tag and user reviews (thank god steam has this features), if it would be upfront about the fact that it is F2P idler game i would had no issues with it and frankly wouldn't even bother downloading it

A fun cookie clicker with factory elements and a gross mobile-esque monitization model looming over it's shoulder. 
My message to the devs: Take your drip-fed microtransaction BS back to the app store, and let me just buy the game once without worrying about how you have molested the game's balance to push me into giving you endless amounts of money. 

I don't play mobile games for this exact reason, and I suggest you avoid this game if you feel the same.

I like the game. 
But there are a few things I wish would be addressed:
1)if you click a input or output there is no way of unlicking the link. 
2)A better description of what each item does. Like how the allocator works and so on.
3)A way to save a game. I know games like this have a feature that will let you start over but with improved time. 

Please fix bugs and make better,.

Extremely interesting concept, but the fact that genuinely useful items and stuff that is necessary to achieve anywhere near optimal production is locked behind a currency that you can only realistically get a finite amount of without paying real money is unfair and ridiculous

LOVE THE GAME COOL CONCEPT BUT..... the first processor unlock causes the entire game to crash so i wish i could play m ore of it but the darn thing crashes everytime i buy the proscessor unlock please fix so i can keep playing!

It's a Idle games masked as a factory builder, has some depth (there is a tiny learning curve later when you start with programming). The network has a bottleneck which means having veriety has no meaning if you want to maximize your profit. 

I won't spend much time on this game, as you can bypass the paywall by simply editing your save and the idle part is gets tedious very quickly, rendering progress useless. 
I'm only playing around to see what is offered, I like the concept...

I played until "programming" was unlocked because I had some hope that there was some actual programming in it, but no, it's just more of the same. I guess it's just not my cup of tea. 

There are some bugs in the interface that makes it really annoying to play, prob from being originally a mobile game. Also there are too many currencies that don't really fit together, so you get many separate systems that don't really talk to each other.

UI is poorly designed (connection lines cross underneath panels), it's a flowchart designer's nightmare.

What each new panel does is unclear, some panels have no final connection to use or sell the item. 

29 minutes and I'm done
It's an interesting Idle game but still an idle game. You could go do something productive instead of getting distracted by this.

Disclaimer at the end of review where I still kinda recommend the game.

I was enjoying it, until I got to "coding"...
You get float, int, Bool and char and you need to combine these in various different ways to make upgrades... How do you combine them? Well... I have no idea.
I've tried googling it, I've tried doing random ones. I can't work it out.
I know you can use the same one twice, so that makes trial and error take a bit longer.

It feels really dumb to have you know how to code to play the game... It's an idle game... gimme a break here, yeah?

So I don't pass the IQ test to play the game, that's my main issue with it.

Other issues include that it's just a complicated mess... I was enjoying sorting it out until I realised there's a prestige mechanic... So you have to spend ages having a nice clean system, putting things together. Which takes quite a long time I'll add... And then you have to... do it again? and again? and again?
That's not even remotely enjoyable.

This is an incremental game, but I wouldn't call it an idle game. Because you have to do a lot to get the numbers to go up.
There's parts of it where it is essentially just leave it going while you sleep. (Which is why I'm at 9 hours. I don't sleep very long sadly.) Which is fine, it's an idle game with a lot of interaction. I'm okay with that...
But then you also have to spend ages sorting everything out, then working out what combines with what. In the coding area...
If the game had a guide to the coding within the game... I wouldn't be so negative on it. Overall, I've enjoyed most of the time I've spent on this.
But this part of the game really does ruin it for me. Because it feels like there's this weird external knowledge barrier on continuation, and the game doesn't tell you how to play it.
It'd be like if a game suddenly started speaking French, and just expected you to know how to speak French. Or if Le r√©dacteur du commentaire s'est soudainement mis √† √©crire en fran√ßais et s'attendait simplement √† ce que vous suiviez le rythme. (I used google translate, this is probably gibberish. Sorry. I cannot speak enough french to get by. XD)

The game does have a guide, what it really should have done is had a link to a bit in the guide where it tells you what the codes are, or said in the tooltip "Check the guide for details."
But all it does say in the guide is "Provides code speed based on your contribution level. Contribution level can be upgraded by inserting contribution" Which is a very weird sentence.
Honestly... I think even if the coding were better explained, I'd still recommend against the game... But less harshly. The prestige mechanic does kill it a bit.

It's free though, so even though I recommend against it.... I still recommend you try it for yourself. Because you don't have anything to lose if you don't like it, and chances are you'll enjoy it more than I did if this is the kind of game for you.
Steam asks if I would recommend this game to other players, and my brain takes that literal... I wouldn't... I'd never be in conversation and say "Oh, you should try Upload labs." But here, on this review... Yeah, give it a go, find out for yourself. Good luck. ^_^

needs work as i had a line stuck at the end of my pointer and could not deselect, even after making the connection.
tutorial was telling me to then click on bin but the screen just scrolled down and down and down and the bin was not clickable due to the line still connected to the pointer.

i got past this eventually but then something new unlocked and it uses money generated to create clock speed or something. this stopped my earnings so i removed it and returned all connections to return to earnings again, yet the game acted as if i had removed nothing and i was still earning nothing to collect. i removed all connections and tried reconnecting and still nothing. game effectively broken.

i tried turning it off and turning it on again and lo and behold it did fuck all. uninstalled top make space for a game designed with some imagination instead
